attributes.description: The life cycle of a t-shirt.
attributes.title: T-shirt

attributes.description: Merchants here receive 100-pound bales of clothing from Europe and the US, or, in this case, indirectly from the US via Japan. They sell these clothes in Tanzanian markets known as mitumbas. Our t-shirt fetches a price of $3.00. Men's jeans cost $5.00, far more expensive. In general, men's clothing fetches a higher price because there is less of it. More women shop in the United States, so more of their clothes are donated to poor countries, making the men's apparel more valuable. Winter clothes are also frequently donated, making them far cheaper in comparison to casual wear than here in the USA. Here in the USA, winter clothes tend to be very expensive. Of course, everything is more expensive when it's brand new.
attributes.title: Exported here

attributes.description: The Japanese people receive used clothing from the United States. They're the biggest consumers of these clothes, but like the Americans, soon they're finished with the clothing as well, and they ship our t-shirt to Tanzania.
attributes.title: Exported here

attributes.description:
Here, at the headquarters of Tesco, our t-shirt is stored in the mass warehouses until it is ready to be shipped to retail stores. From here it will go to the United States.
Tesco is one of the move environmentally friendly companies, promising an LCA not unlike this one for all of its products.
attributes.title: Stored here

attributes.description: Once Person was done wearing their shirt, they donated it to the Trans-America Trading Company. The Trans-America Trading Company processes more than 12 million pounds of used clothing each year. They reuse it for several different purposes - 30% of the textiles are transformed into absorbent wiping rags, about 25-30% are turned into fiber stuffing for upholstery, and 45% of the clothes are shipped to countries looking for vintage American clothing. Japan is the biggest consumer of used American clothing, so our t-shirt was shipped from NJ to Japan.
attributes.title: Donated here

attributes.description:
Thousands of workers labor here for ten hours a day, sometimes just to earn the equivalent of 1 USD. They take the materials and the designs sent by the USA and make our t-shirt.
China is actually the top exporter of apparel, account for 30% of the world's fashion. They export our t-shirt back to the Tesco company, headquartered in Britain.
attributes.title: Manufactured here

attributes.description: Cotton Incorporated fields, where they farm cotton to make t-shirts. This cotton is then sent to the factories in China. Although China also produces cotton, the American companies will probably only trust their own exports to make their products.
attributes.address: Temple Airport Incorporated Airport, Temple, OK 73568, USA
attributes.title: Cotton farmed here

attributes.description: Some big-shot designer designed this shirt and sent the idea to China to have the t-shirt manufactured by the milions.
attributes.title: Designed here

attributes.description:
This is where Person purchased the t-shirt in Seattle, Washington, from a Tesco branch.
Statistically, only 21% of annual clothing purchases are kept by the consumer, and so this t-shirt is used, worn, and loved, then donated away.
attributes.title: Purchased here
Donated here to Exported from USA to here
Exported from USA to here to Exported from Japan to here
Cotton farmed here to Manufactured here
